Description: Body sherd of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of neck with added red and chest with ham-frill collar of a cock or hen, to right, and the lower part of draped figure to left, with advanced foot and part of long chiton decorated with wavy lines; red on alternate folds and lower border of chequer pattern with red dot in each square; below, dilute line.
Curator's comments: The sherd probably belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1924,1201.206, 1924,1201.342 and 1888,0601.550.a. According to Lemos, the female figure may be a goddess. The sherd belongs to the group of Chian black-figured vases bearing Laconising features. According to Williams, the kylix is by the same painter as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.2 and AN1896-1908-G.133.6, whom he has identified as the Sirens Painter. The Sirens Painter pieces most closely resemble those by the Boreads Painter, primarily because of the single pomegranate band on the tondo of the Oxford kylix.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 157-60, p. 324, no. 1464, pl. 193)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 130, p. 132 note 66)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0873) (phase 2)
